SENT.plain: We demonstrate that treatment with the cytokine human interferon-beta (IFN-beta) resulted in a beneficial outcome in a rabbit model of thromboembolic cerebral ischemia

Rabbits administered subcutaneously with IFN-beta prior to (pre-treatment) or after (post-treatment) the introduction of an autologous blood clot into the middle cerebral artery have consistently smaller subcortical infarct volumes compared to control (untreated) counterparts
The average subcortical infarct volume of pre-treatment rabbits is 46.3+/-9.3 mm(3) (n=4), and that of post-treatment rabbit is 40.0+/-23.1 mm(3) (n=4)
Both are significantly lower (P=0.003 and P=0.004, respectively) than the average subcortical infarct volume of control rabbits (121.6+/-32.9 mm(3), n=5)

Although the precise mechanism responsible for the beneficial effect of IFN-beta on stroke is not yet clear, our results are in line with the known anti-inflammatory potential and anti-apoptotic function of IFN-beta
